But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan, where you transition from farmland to small tourist towns. There are no large city malls, no Walmart, Target, or even an Applebee's. You must drive to reach any destination. Despite this, I reside in one of the world's most beautiful places, surrounded by water. My "city" is encircled by water, with beautiful Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go, you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood reflects the essence of a small town. Houses aren't stacked against each other, nor are they cookie-cutter homes. They are older homes, with some being updated and remodeled, while others remain older. Most homes have basements, visible from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood feature older aluminum siding. The blocks surrounding my house have homes of every imaginable color. Most houses have yards with trampolines and playsets. Some people have gardens and fences for their animals. The houses symbolize Middle America, with hardworking people who work for a living, either raising families or having raised them already. On any given day, you will see kids running up and down the streets, people walking dogs, biking, and rollerblading. Neighbors know each other, and you can tell who belongs and who doesn't. You'll see someone grilling outside and wave, or see someone walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile warmly. Lawns are well-maintained, with no piles of leaves from fall. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards, they are neatly trimmed. It's not a neighborhood that impresses with its beautiful homes, but it's one that makes you think it would be a good place to raise a family. It's quiet, peaceful, and safe. While it may look average, it is exceptional because it represents what people want in the world—a safe place to end the day. Within walking distance are the county sheriff's department and jail, with the health department right next to it. The city recycling center is just down the road, providing services utilized by neighbors and residents from the city. Nearby, we have baseball and softball fields where you can hear announcers keeping score and calling player names. Our small town airport is next door, and you can hear the rumble of small planes taking off and landing while playing outside or even indoors. You can walk to get ice cream from a local shop, and if you're up for it, you can walk downtown from our neighborhood. My kids can bike to the park, which is about eight blocks away. It's truly a great place to live.

The area where I live can be described as a typical cookie-cutter suburb. In my neighborhood, the presence of a homeowner's association is very evident. Upon entering, you'll see only well-maintained single-family homes, thanks in part to the homeowner's association. The front yards are all similar, with small patches of landscaped grass, decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Occasionally, you'll see small trees. Each house has a two-car garage. As you drive through the neighborhood, you'll notice newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition with no potholes. Most houses are single-story, but you'll sometimes see two-story ones. We don't have the typical mailbox setup you would expect for single-family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house; instead, there's a large group of mailboxes at the end of the street, similar to apartments. Everyone uses a key to access their mailbox, and there are two larger lockers for packages. Again, this uniformity is thanks to the HOA. My house is on the far edge of a nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburban. As a result, we have plenty of land for various activities. There are multiple community pools accessible to anyone living here, well-maintained and gated. There are also various walking trails for walking your dog or taking an evening stroll alone. You don't need to visit a park to exercise. The neighborhood is large enough to run around and get sufficient exercise. Most of the community consists of retired people. It's a very safe area where everyone looks out for each other. Additionally, we have a small number of middle-aged and young professionals. Regarding the city, it is surprisingly large in population but has a small-town feel. We have most of the amenities you expect and rely on. For example, we have one mall. It's not huge, but it serves its purpose. For me, it takes about 15 minutes of driving to reach any significant place, but once there, I'm greeted with various stores to choose from. We have everything from high-end grocery stores with organic food to bargain outlets with a limited selection of items and minimal staff to keep costs down. Overall, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and quite typical. We have many nice features, like pools and walking trails. Although we aren't right next to any shopping areas, you can easily drive to any major chain store you like.

The first time I heard about my place was while listening to a podcast about missing people. It was a bit surprising. Almost every apartment in the area costs over a thousand dollars a month. I had never heard of that story, nor had any of my friends. Maybe that's the struggle. I know a few friends who cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned to be frugal over the years. You start to appreciate the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. As an adult, your sense of smell dulls. You might start smoking, or maybe you're just too used to it all. But the flea market always stands out. The adult smell is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It gets into the leather and stays even after washing. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. If you start from the far side, you can visit two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is busy, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you never hear it in the thrift stores. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store remains silent. It's a nice place to spend an afternoon. There are more and more of these places every year. Cars and people flood it. It's called a developing city. As the headquarters of one of the largest e-commerce and delivery empires, it still shows growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone and everything is focused on their own goals, and nobody expects much from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you be. It's not like the South, where showing concern means you care. Here, you don't really pry into anyone's life. You can keep up your shell as long as you want, and the city will ebb and flow like waves on the beach. It's a lively place. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, there's always something happening. In a way, our apartment is more a community of friends than a group of strangers. We come together when needed, celebrate birthdays, mourn losses, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I try to clean up after myself and leave them food, and they do the same. I bring them mail, and they do the same for me. It's nice to see them, and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I enjoy theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't completely ruin my life.

I reside in a small Midwestern town located just beyond the suburbs of a major city. My neighborhood, situated on the town's east side, is considered the most economically challenged area. Property values are low, with most homes rented or owned by low-income residents. Nevertheless, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly, often greeting me with smiles and hellos as I walk by. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, remain relatively low. In the past decade, there have been a few violent crimes within a few blocks of my home, including some shootings and at least one murder. Last year, our next-door neighbors tragically lost their son in a shooting outside a local bar. Fortunately, apart from occasionally losing items left on our porch, our family hasn't been directly impacted by crime. Overall, the town where I live has been significantly affected by the "opioid epidemic" that has troubled many regions of the United States. Many lives have been claimed by fentanyl overdoses. Luckily, there are numerous resources in my town to tackle this crisis, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those battling addiction. Despite these challenges, the town boasts many positive aspects. My son's elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support personnel. Despite his special needs, he has not faced bullying thanks to the school's incredibly positive environment, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that organizes multiple events annually to encourage family involvement and educational advancement. Since over 20% of our town's population lives below the poverty line, the elementary school offers free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry. No child or family is treated as "less than" due to inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made numerous improvements to our town's appearance, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most improvements have occurred in the town center and west side, where shopping areas are located and most traffic flows. The east side, where I reside, is often overlooked, which is a sore point for residents in my neighborhood. Overall, I enjoy living in this town. The people are generally friendly, the schools are excellent, and there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retailers) to meet my family's needs. Our home might not be worth much, but it is comfortable and sufficient. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.

My neighborhood is rich in culture. Situated on a hill, it's surrounded by buildings with historical significance. I live in a seven-story apartment building right across from an old live theater. Just a block down the hill is a charming arcade bar that attracts diverse groups on warm summer nights. Often, especially on weekend nights in June and July, you can see people lining up to enter. A few blocks away is the nearest city park, which is quite large for its urban location. The park is encircled by concrete with tall steps built into its walls. During the cold winter months, homeless people set up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalks and steps. It doesn't snow much, but the heavy winter rains make it hard to stay warm. By setting up their tents close together in the city center rather than on the outskirts, they stay warmer. They are also within walking distance of the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city isn't just its historic architecture—the tall, proud buildings scattered throughout the hills that roll down to the ocean. What I cherish about my neighborhood is the culture of its people. Hilltop was once known as the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. Even three decades later, stories of federal officials and the DEA sweeping through the streets are still told. The people remember, and these stories are passed down through generations to newcomers like me. The residents work hard to keep it clean, even though it's still seen as a tough neighborhood. They care about what happens in their city, on their block. There's a saying that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around Hilltop after dark. I believe this warning is a relic of the past, tinged with social conditioning. Perhaps I am dark enough to not be seen as entirely "white," or maybe Hilltop sees me as one of their own, someone who is painfully aware of the reminders that constantly afflict our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions arise from ignorance and fear, even in a city that's supposed to be a cultural melting pot. I know one thing: no matter how far I wander, Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who are more likely to offer me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open a little longer so I could charge my phone when I had nowhere to escape from the rain. It's a place where I've sat, thinking I'm invisible, huddled against concrete storefronts on the dreariest nights, only to have someone stop, look me in the eye, hand me $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I moved to this neighborhood just as I was about to start eighth grade. Initially, making friends was tough, but eventually, I became close to someone who lived two houses away and another person on my street. Although they don't live here anymore, the memories remain. Most of the people who lived here when I first arrived are still around. My neighborhood is similar to a typical American suburban area, with many two-story houses. On weekends or warm days, I hear kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most of the time. I've never had issues with anyone here. You're left alone unless you need help. I've ordered many packages online, and none have been stolen from my porch. I trust my neighbors. There's a park just a minute or two from my house where I have many memories. I've played basketball, football, and baseball there with others from the neighborhood. One of my worst memories is from there too, when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad ones. Nowadays, I go to the park to spend time with my cousin's kids. They're much younger and still enjoy swings and slides. Just thinking about the park excites them. The park now makes me feel nostalgic for various reasons. The neighborhood is very diverse, offering all kinds of food nearby. Within a one-mile radius, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, many people now use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash for food delivery. Fast food places are the most popular, but you can find them near any suburban area. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here have everything you need. There are several dry cleaners nearby. There's a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street, along with a Jewel-Osco grocery store, popular in the Midwest. Some stores are quite diverse, like an Indian-owned shop where you can get ingredients or ready-made Indian food. Overall, I appreciate my neighborhood. Reading horror stories on social media or the news about others' experiences with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.

My neighborhood is near the college I attend, which makes living here enjoyable for me. The area is mostly filled with apartment buildings, along with a few fun and reasonably priced restaurants and bars. One bar was recently renamed and is pricier, but the service and drinks aren't too bad. People here are generally nice, mostly college students or lower-income residents, since the apartments are affordable. There are many children nearby because there's an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don't know my neighbors and prefer it that way, as they smoke a lot of marijuana. The building management placed an air freshener unit outside their door, which my boyfriend and I find funny. It seems almost insulting. The buildings around here often look old, though their interiors might be renovated. A bit further down the street are brand new apartments, but I don't like them because their construction isn't very good. They're cheaply made but have high rent, which I think is a scam, but the management can get away with it due to their proximity to campus. There's a very cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates, mostly microwaved. Across from it is a gas station, which I've heard isn't a good place to work. Thanks to some city funds, the road was redone last summer, adding a wide sidewalk and lots of grass on the medians and sides, making the area a bit nicer. However, my apartment building is surrounded by trees. Some were cut down, so there are a few stumps, but there are still more trees here than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and another set of apartments. I live on 42nd Street, but right behind is 43rd Street, which isn't as nice. The sidewalks there are in poor condition and crumbling, and most buildings look shabby. There are a lot of trees on that street, probably to hide the buildings' appearance. Most of the crime in this area happens at an apartment complex on that street, but I can't blame them entirely, as there are apartments across from me with a lot of crime and a transient population. Still, I think I like living here. It's affordable, with plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially like having the university within walking distance and two bus stops, making it easy to get to the store and downtown.

My neighborhood consists of duplexes in a cul-de-sac, placed at intervals to resemble individual houses. The only difference is that each one is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, although not all, is friends with each other. Some evenings, we gather at the end of an unassigned driveway to chat while the neighborhood kids play with toys, draw with sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. It is refreshing in this modern world filled with machinery and computers. It feels like a step back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees, enhanced by blue skies and white clouds. The only drawback? This season, we have experienced tornado warnings, and last night, for the first time, we heard actual tornado sirens, prompting us to seek shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub clutching my smallest dog, along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog, uninterested in the bathroom, stayed in the living room, nervous and barking due to the unusual circumstances. The neighborhood was silent except for the sound of large hailstones hitting the ground. After the storm, the road was literally steaming due to the temperature change. Within minutes, the temperature dropped from 92 to 75 degrees. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. As I looked up at the clearing sky, the sun appeared, and it started to rain. A double rainbow appeared. I rushed inside, grabbed my camera, and quickly took pictures to share with my friends and family on Facebook. They were in awe, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour until some people finally returned home from wherever they had been when the thunderstorm hit. Then life returned to normal, with mothers and children outside while dinner was being cooked. For someone who recently moved from New Hampshire to North Carolina, this is such a friendly neighborhood. I love the southern accent people speak with. I have a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment, as does everyone. Although all the houses look the same on the outside, not all apartments are the same inside. Some are actually quite small. I find this puzzling. I enjoy walking along the largest field behind my home and strolling down to a pond that is not meant for swimming. I've seen deer, and in the mornings, you can hear the giant bullfrog singing. This is a fantastic place to live, just forty minutes from the city of Charlotte. Each morning is greeted by the crowing of roosters from the surrounding farms. It's like living in a small village community of its own. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm whose braying in the evening lets us know it's there. I was fortunate to find this gem of a neighborhood.

Considering I've been here for around ten years, I suppose I can share what I know. Initially, I felt quite sad when I first arrived in the neighborhood. Moving from Riverdale to Stockbridge was tough, and I cried because I missed and loved the people there. However, my parents wanted the best for my sister and me, so we moved to a better area with improved housing and schools. Everything in our new neighborhood was considered "not ghetto." Over the years, I got used to it, made new friends and a few school enemies. I didn’t get to know my neighbors well, except for Mr. Glen and his kids, and Dennis, who lived next to us. They were wonderful people, almost like family, and I truly appreciated them. I remember attending Mr. Glen’s wedding with my mom, dad, and sister (they remarried), which was incredibly fun and something I look forward to experiencing myself one day when I build my own wealth and give my future wife a queen's life. During the wedding, when Ms. Veda, Mr. Glen’s wife, tossed her garter, I caught it! Unfortunately, I didn’t catch the bouquet. We danced all night, and I enjoyed spending time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven't seen her since, and I hope she has moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood is like a maze, but now that I have a GPS, I can explore more. I’ve only ventured out with friends Kason and Curtis. We used to play video games a lot and enjoy life to the fullest. Sometimes, I would go to the park to appreciate nature, which calms my soul and brings me peace. I also practice balancing with sticks from Home Depot and bring along my wooden bokken when I can. I find joy in doing what I love. There’s a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played in a while, it’s great to have them if I ever want to pick it up again. My dad, my best friend, and Mr. Graves introduced me to tennis, and we always had a fantastic time. They pushed us hard, but it was always fun. I’ve had a lot of fun in this neighborhood, with many stories to tell, but these memories stand out, and I believe the best is yet to come!

My neighborhood is a quaint little town. It doesn't stand out from other places in South Carolina but plays a significant role in the agriculture sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, proudly displayed on the welcome sign. The area mainly consists of farmland, either peach orchards or cattle fields. Houses outside the town center are spaced widely apart; most are two stories with metal roofs to combat the intense summer heat or gray shingles. Often, these houses are set back from the road to allow the front fields to be used for animals or crops. In the town center, a single traffic light hangs at a four-way intersection. This is where the town's only stores are located. You can get "fast food" at three places: Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, but it closed recently. There's a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug, amusingly known for its Cherry Coca-Cola. The town has a small but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, commonly referred to as IGA. Though it's the only grocery store, many people just stop by for one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville for their main shopping. The most popular store in town is Dollar General, offering a wide range of everyday items and often bustling from opening to closing! There's a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman well-known in the community. The store has been in Johnston for many years and even employs two movers to deliver purchased furniture! Next to the furniture store is a small pet groomer called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They offer numerous services like daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's office and a veterinary practice are situated away from the town center; they are small but well-equipped to serve Johnston's residents. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. After completing fifth grade, students have to attend middle and high school in the neighboring town. Technically, there are no parks in town, but they are currently developing a 2.5-acre recreational area to provide more family outing opportunities and attract visitors and potential residents. Admittedly, there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, pet walking areas, or a variety of restaurants. Despite this, it's a nice town, so small you might pass through it in the blink of an eye without realizing it!

I reside in a typical suburban area in a small southern town in Tennessee. Our street connects two state highways, so we experience a bit more traffic than I would prefer, but overall, it's a quiet neighborhood. Not many people move in or out, so I've become familiar with most of the residents. People usually keep busy with yard work and other daily chores. In winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house on the street's front corner, which allows us to see everyone coming and going throughout the day, and we're familiar with the cars people drive here. Whenever we notice an unfamiliar vehicle, we take note of it. Some neighbors go for walks either for exercise or to walk their dogs. Children play on their bikes, just as you would expect. We spend a lot of time at home since we work from here. There are four of us: myself, my wife, and our two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen. So, I believe others are used to seeing us come and go as well. We enjoy playing outside, sometimes even in the rain. Occasionally, we grill on our back deck, and the barbecue smell is always pleasant. It seems someone is always mowing around here, and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March until around October, when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood has many trees since it was once a wooded area, providing plenty of shade, but there are also lots of leaves in the fall. This means we rake and burn the leaves annually. I enjoy the smell of burning leaves as well, so it's a nice sign of fall's arrival. Lately, we've had little winter to speak of, making it feel like an extended fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door unless someone knocks, which is rare. I like working on my truck or other projects in the garage from time to time, and when the garage doors are open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. It's quite peaceful here during the holidays. Thanksgiving brings some neighbors hosting out-of-town visitors, and there are extra cars parked everywhere at that time. The same happens on other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. All in all, I enjoy living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.

My neighborhood is right in the center of the high desert, where there's nothing but dirt everywhere. For those who haven't lived here, they might not truly grasp the constant sight of brown, and when you spot a lawn, you realize that person is spending a fortune on it. When I first moved here in the 90s, houses were very spread out. It's still mostly the same, with lots of new buildings. Honestly, this place looks more like a city every day, but it seems most places are changing similarly. People are usually very friendly, but like any city, there are good and bad areas. In my neighborhood, I'm surrounded by friendly older folks, which makes it a nice area. The stores around here are mostly chains like Food for Less and Smart & Final. If you're looking for upscale options, you have to travel further; I rarely see Whole Foods or similar stores. The most prominent jobs here are in construction, though this isn't based on official data. I think it's because the city is still underdeveloped, with plenty of open land to build on. This worries me a bit, as I like things as they are now. I left a big city and have no desire to go back. Speaking of construction, this is my full-time job field; I'm a drywall and T-bar installer. What I like about my home is the variety of animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, one of which is the unique beauty of the desert itself. The high desert's climate and terrain have created challenging ecosystems that need protection and are home to various wildlife. Human residents here should take time to learn about these non-human neighbors to coexist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted well to the wildlife. I have three children, and they are all fascinated by lizards and desert bugs. As I write this, they are outside trying to catch different specimens. Regarding attractions, we have a few. Additionally, Victorville is a great place for families to experience the desert in a different way. If possible, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with activities and fun in true Victorville style. Drop by nearby Wrightwood to see the snow-covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to conclude your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's societal and industrial development.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I believe my answer is somewhat unique. While most respondents might be homeowners with independent lives, my situation is a bit different. I consider the college campus where I reside as my neighborhood, and the people living in my dorm as my community. I also view the surrounding campus as part of my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this uniqueness, my neighborhood shares some similarities with the traditional concept of a neighborhood. Like any conventional neighborhood, mine has houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start by discussing the "houses" in my neighborhood. Before exploring them, it's important to clarify the types of housing available. There are three types of housing nearby: apartments, actual houses, and dormitories. In the apartments, typically there are 2-4 people per room, with about 4-6 rooms per floor. The most common buildings have about 2 floors, accommodating around 20 people each. Next, there are actual houses available for rent by those affiliated with the school, usually 2-4 bedroom setups often housing alumni. However, these are few and far between as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms housing hundreds of students, with usually two people per room, and this is the most common type in my neighborhood. With housing covered, we can move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity, reflected in the composition of my neighborhood. It includes people from various cultures and ages. Most professional staff live in the neighborhood's houses, new students stay in dormitory-style housing, and older students reside in apartment-style housing. Simply talking about the people doesn't do them justice, so let's move on to the stores and parks. My school, being a self-contained neighborhood, boasts numerous stores and a single park. The stores offer typical dining options found elsewhere, along with the school's unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. Thus, anything needed can be found within the boundaries of my neighborhood! Additionally, the park is a playground for the diverse community and is maintained clean and safe by all neighborhood members!

There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to slope downward, with my house sitting at the top of the steepest hill in the area. It's known as the "workout hill" because many joggers like to run up it during their exercise routines. Since there are no sidewalks on my street, everyone walks on the road. The road has some potholes, making it feel a bit dangerous to drive on. The telephone and electric wires around the block appear worn and tattered. It rains and storms frequently here, causing branches and debris to often knock down power lines, and repeated repairs give them a patchy appearance. Tall evergreen trees are everywhere, but people here dislike them because they block the ocean view. This is why many houses are built high up, with large glass-fronted second stories to overlook the bay. It's beautiful at sunset when the water seems to glow from below and the sky turns orange. However, it is often cloudy, so most sunlight is seen through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car in the driveway for a month, and when I went to use it, it was green and furry with moss, taking me three hours to scrape it all off. Children are not common around here, though there's a school a few blocks away. Most people in my neighborhood are older and retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them lounging on lawns or racing down the street. If you leave a door or window open, they might sneak into your house. I once found one in my living room and had to shoo it out the front door. Rabbits run wild here; some are quite large, and gardeners dislike them for digging up plant roots and burrowing in lawns. My cats love them though and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also have the usual birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and occasionally a hawk or eagle flies by until the neighborhood crows chase it away. There aren't any stores nearby, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront, there are a few restaurants serving fresh seafood. There's not much of a beach, but the rocks along the shore are fun to throw into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shore clearly even on most misty days.

If you plan to visit Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you won't have trouble finding it! Public transportation is very convenient and is one of the most popular modes of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurst is quite an urban neighborhood, so you'll still feel the New York City vibe. During your visit, be ready to see many Asian stores around. Over the last twenty years, Bensonhurst has seen a significant influx of Asian residents. Because of this, you'll see at least one Asian-owned store on every block as you walk. Supermarkets and laundromats are particularly popular. These businesses are very popular among locals since the supermarket's food quality is excellent, prices are cheaper, and they are very convenient. Near where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking distance of each other, adding to the convenience of grocery shopping. I'm not saying Bensonhurst is solely populated by Asian residents, though. It's quite diverse, with immigrants and their first and second-generation American children. Most large and popular businesses in the area are Asian-owned. Besides these Asian-owned businesses, there's also a recently renovated park nearby, which has about ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for children, and even a fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we're in New York City, the parks are, of course, very diverse. You'll see all sorts of people here, playing and getting along well. In this neighborhood, there aren't many large corporate buildings. The buildings you'll find are mostly for co-op living or condominium apartments. However, most living spaces here are two-family houses. Most people are nice, though very noisy. Every day, you'll hear cars blasting music or revving their engines, waking you up in the morning. If you plan to visit at night, you should stay alert. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people can be unpredictable. You might encounter people looking for trouble for no reason, bullies, and thieves. I myself was bullied in this neighborhood in the past, but that was many years ago. A recent incident involved package theft. Although common, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Lastly, even though New York City fines people for not cleaning up after their dogs, people here don't follow the rules. Every morning, you'll see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station or supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the ground everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!

The first thing you need to understand about Portland, Oregon is the meaning of "weird." The unofficial city motto, "Keep Portland Weird," is painted on the back of a building that serves as a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club, often skirting the law in at least some of these roles. For some people, this slogan is a call to remember Portland from the 90s and early 2000s, when it was less famous and more affordable, fostering creative and unique subcultures. For others, it is an invitation—come to Portland, where being called weird is now a compliment. Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the endless construction of condos to house them, Portland remains weird. Being weird doesn't always mean being accepting, but it does mean embracing things that are usually not accepted. Weird doesn't mean we lack modern comforts and struggles. Just like the rest of the country, we buy most of our goods from China. There are countless ways to be weird, to be different, but Portland also has its share of normal. Portland has yoga, hipsters, and business professionals. Maybe weird means we just don't take it all too seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many parts of Portland, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summer. Traditionally, free boxes are cardboard boxes with items someone is giving away, but they can also be plastic bags or containers. They often contain something magical, a perfect treasure for the passerby, surprisingly often. Free boxes typically have clothes and books, but they can hold anything. The magical potential of strolling through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. At least, that's what Portland means to me, but I am just one kind of weird among thousands. Some people I live with would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with actual goats) or attend Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who chase our dreams, or dream of chasing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug issues often stem from mental health problems, and the constant rain for much of the year, along with the gloomy clouds, seems to contribute. Portland also has a homelessness problem, which no one seems to know how to address. The homeless are drawn by Portland's social services, better than in most parts of the country, but still inadequate, as everywhere else. The non-homeless population oscillates between care and disdain. In this, we are not weird at all.

The mountains are always present. In the north, they witness the journey of the sun each dawn and dusk. Regardless of how much I forget them or get absorbed in work and life, they remain steadfast, unmoved by life's challenges. On days when I am most stressed, they demand my attention, and when I turn to them, they calm my anxious heart, providing strength to carry on, day by day. I first moved here when I began my undergraduate studies, and it was the mountains north of campus that initially captivated me. Certainly, the university boasts stunning buildings, ponds, and trees, which hold a piece of my heart, but it is the mountains that truly reign supreme. The rest of the town has its own unique beauty. Countless cafes have hosted many caffeine-fueled study sessions. One can walk or take a bus to the downtown area, where the faded bricks of restaurants and office buildings create an aura of antiquity. Here, this seemingly suburban town displays as much hustle and vigor as its neighboring city. This liveliness doesn’t last many blocks though, as one can return to the serene small town atmosphere by passing the library. This contrast of environments in such proximity gives the city a magical vibe, as if inviting exploration. It’s easy to create cherished memories, each tied to a specific part of town. Whether it's walking past rusty swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or rushing through the bustling downtown to catch a movie at the fancy theater with university-provided tickets. Alas, it also holds many harsh memories, as all places inevitably do. The ponds, especially, are fitting for reflection or crying sessions during a 2 a.m. existential crisis—something I have more experience with. Watching turtles, ducks, and insects live their lives, each contributing in their own way, I couldn't help but ponder my own purpose while navigating this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, the park, and the suburban houses, until I reached a main street. Then, the sun shone brilliantly on the palm trees, painting the sky, and as I looked at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they always had been. The sturdy, imposing mountains brushed against the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building on the horizon, and as if speaking without words, they stirred a sense of perseverance within me.

At first glance, you might overlook it—after all, it's just a residential area behind a shopping strip, not typically seen as a desirable place to live. However, if you walk past the abandoned Whole Foods and continue behind the hotels that only fill up during summer family reunions, you'll discover a bustling community. On these streets are several apartment complexes, carefully aligned like meticulously dismantled Russian nesting dolls along the road. The first apartments you encounter have been in the news for some unsavory activities, so let's not dwell on them—appearances can be deceiving. The complexes next to them, however, offer a world that few people know about. Across from these complexes is a community college satellite campus, a quiet set of buildings where students arrive with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 a.m. to start their sleepy day. The iron gates creak open one by one, while commuters outside shake their fists, frustrated by the traffic on crowded days. The road intersects another residential street, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for those with unfortunate injuries. The center features cheerful porch furniture and a lazily spinning ceiling fan that stirs the warm summer air. Children run back and forth across the park's grass, cartwheeling over the prickly green stalks, while bees hover lazily around the flowers. Retired folks walk their dogs, frowning at skateboarders and nodding politely at teenage girls gossiping by the playground. Nearby, a strip mall hosts a sushi place with cheap food that’s never too busy, a swim supply store, and a nail salon. You could fill your pool, get a manicure, and eat hibachi chicken all at once—the charm of a strip mall. There's also a DIY frozen yogurt place, where teens often clutch sweating cups of yogurt topped with extras, doing skateboard tricks and vaping, thinking it's the coolest. This neighborhood is a slice of Americana—a piece of history in the sleepy South where almost nothing changes, not even time.

My neighborhood is quite fascinating. Most of the houses are single-family dwellings, but a few have been divided into two sections while still being connected, if that makes sense. My home has a small front yard and a small driveway to the left. Like most of the others, it recalls a time not long ago when living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream once seemed to embrace the nation's people, but now it's drifting away. Yet, my neighborhood and many others still remain, still signaling to us and visitors that the dream is alive, and we are holding onto it as best as we can. People aren't as optimistic as they once were, and the maintenance of the small yards isn't what it used to be, but there are still one or two cars in every driveway, and the youth still play as if the world around them were their entire existence. The public school, which has been here for nearly 90 years, still stands, seemingly inspiring today's youth while evoking nostalgia among older residents. Churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts remain full. All the homes look different but feel the same. There's a large supermarket called Super "A" owned by a large Yemeni family, who are possibly the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of residents are African American. The streets are wide, and the kids usually play football, only pausing to let cars pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations, and many can share stories of a past when everyone knew everyone. There used to be a karate school, but when Hollywood stopped making Karate Kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be karate kids, so it's now a pharmacy because, as I've heard, drugs make everything better. There's also a small movie theater that shows old films at a discounted price, avoided by the youth due to its lack of new releases, but favored by the elders, who see it as a small price for a night out without kids. There is a single expressway that passes through my town, though the exits and entrances are in the neighboring town. There was once a petition for an exit in our town. The youth supported it, but the elders opposed it, believing the expressway would ruin the town, and they eventually convinced the city council to deny the request. They are building a new high school, and we're trying to decide on a mascot for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would best represent my town.

Since I live in a big city, my neighborhood is highly diverse. Residential areas are scattered seemingly at random among commercial zones, where various businesses operate. Some of these businesses consist of offices, while others are shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There is no shortage of new restaurants to try or shops to explore. While some stores are large, well-known brands owned by big corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only found in various malls but also line the streets, often within walking distance of otherwise quiet and peaceful neighborhoods, which are surrounded by many points of interest. There are also a few nearby parks, and I've noticed people often visit these parks with their young children. Speaking of people, there is quite a bit of diversity in my neighborhood. In a small area, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a number of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Extending a bit beyond my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they sometimes form their own small communities within the city. We have areas known as Korea Town, China Town, Little Armenia, and others, just a few miles away. However, these few miles can lead to a very long drive. A distance of only 10 miles can sometimes take two hours to cover due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere. While certain places of interest are inevitably nearby, the city is vast, and people generally do not prefer to commute on foot. Consequently, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and finding parking spots is challenging almost everywhere. Ironically, there has been a lot of construction in recent years as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in and more vehicles on the roads. However, my city has many different types of houses. Not everyone lives in or wants to live in a large apartment building. Residential areas consist of houses of various sizes, smaller apartment buildings, and condominiums. Some properties have single-family homes, while others have duplexes. This is true even within my immediate neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood consists of people of varying ages, and to be honest, I am not familiar with most of my neighbors. It's not really a close-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends from the neighborhood who were all close to my age.

"Is there nothing here?" she asked as we drove past the cornfields that stretched to the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, knowing she'd be shocked by the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk from her house—she had never seen so much open space in her life. Taken aback by the ubiquity of cornfields, I shared with her what it was like growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from. Driving along the two-lane country road, you reach a quarry filled with water. Just beyond it is the small development where I live. The houses are mostly made of brick and stucco. Each house sits on at least a half-acre of land, which everyone takes pride in maintaining. In springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the Midwestern trees that change with each season. The driveways are filled with high-end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my gray stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly smile. He spends the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over the hum of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood finds him amusing, but he is always genuine and a remarkable person with a unique history. He has grown older and lost some of his sharpness with age. In the past, he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional "moo" from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This is where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to 'hunting' animals (which mostly involved chasing them), there was always something to do, and usually, a neighborhood child was available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully harsh, yet nothing is more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once held vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into bare skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland, we played pretend during a time when nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them.
